newsitem.title: USA: Bradys fall sharply amid U.S. rate fears, Dow drop.
newsitem.headline: Bradys fall sharply amid U.S. rate fears, Dow drop.

text.p: Brady bond prices ended off sharply across the board amid continued nervousness over the U.S. interest rate environment as evidenced by a rocky trading session in the U.S. stock market, Brady traders said.
Spreads on Brady issues were seen wider by 20 to 30 basis points across the board, traders said.

"This wasn't a Treasury-driven selloff as prices were next to unchanged from Thursday's levels, pure and simple - it's emerging market spread-widening, partially driven by fears about the stock market selloff," said one Brady trader.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended a volatile trading session off 157.11 points at 6583.48.
"Primarily its been a dealer-driven down trade," said another trader. "The focus is nothing more important than what interest rates and the stock market, in the U.S., are doing."
The Benchmark U.S. 30-year Treasury bond closed off 5/32 at 94-4/32 to yield 7.10 percent, compared with Thursday's 7.08 percent yield at the close.
At 1730 EST/2230 GMT, Argentine par bonds and Mexican pars fell sharply losing 2 points to trade at 61-7/8 bid, 70 bid, respectively.
Venezuela pars also dropped two points to trade at 69-3/4 bid, while Brazilian "C" bonds were off 1-7/8 at 73-3/4 bid.
"It's 100 percent general market volatility," said Amy Falls, Director of emerging market research at Morgan Stanley & Co Inc.
"In our view there's definitely a connection between the high-yield market and the emerging markets," Falls said.
"What's happended is of course the high-yield market is highly correlated with the Dow," Falls said.
